answers.answer: It's highly likely to be a fungal infection.  And that being so, the creams that you have been using will have no effect.Make an appointment to see your doctor to get a skin swab taken of the area so that it can get sent off to the laboratory for analysis.For fungal infections, you require an antifungal cream that is used on the genitals.  It may also be of benefit to take antifungal medications by mouth as well as the cream.  In between an antifungal cream, you would also benefit from using a moisturising emollient.  You can purchase all these from the pharmacy without a prescription, but I would advise you to see your doctor and get a swab done to find out first if this is a fungal injection.When you take a bath you can put in a handful or two of porridge oats and soak in that and no, it won't clog up your sink hole.  Or, you can have a bath with a large cupful or 2 of Epsom Salts and soak in that.  You will need to put in a few drops of baby oil because Epsom Salts is very drying.  Epsom Salts neutralises the pH on your skin, that the bacteria and fungus does not like.  You can purchase Epsom Salts for use in the bath on line.To get immediate relief from the itching, you can apply natural set yogurt to your washed (don't use normal soap) and gently dried skin.  The yogurt will cool down the itching and reduce the inflammation on the skin.  This home remedy can be used for as long as required.Do you have pre diabetes or diabetes?Taking antibiotics can encourage yeast overgrowth because the antibiotics kill of the good bacteria as well as the bad bacterial.  If you are prone to getting fungal infections when taking antibiotics, ask your doctor to also prescribe an antifungal cream or capsules as well.Being overweight causes sweating and that can encourage yeast growth.  Don't wear manmade fabrics because this can cause more sweating.  Use cotton underpants, avoid wearing nylons.  Wear loose clothing.Don't use normal soaps.  Use non perfumed soaps, the ones that have the same pH level as our skin, baby washes should be fine too.  You can purchase an emollient from the pharmacy that you can use instead of soap.  This will not kill off any bacterial or fungus - you need the appropriate medications for that.  Having broken skin when the spots are raw and bleed, is an entry for bacteria.Have a healthy and well balanced diet with lots of fresh fruit and vegetables and cut our or cut down on your sugary, processed and junk foods.  Cut out or cut down on your alcohol and fizzy drinks too.  Drink more water.  2 litres a day is usually recommended, more if you sweat a lot.Make an appointment to see your doctor to get the correct diagnosis.Let me know how you get on.Best wishes.

question: I'm 45 years old, had a rash on both shins for about 3 mos.  Never had something like this last so long...usually hydrocortisone cream (1%) works pretty quickly if I get a small patch of itchy tiny bumps.  I've tried hyrdocortisone (twice per day) for over a month, and no help.  If anything, it's spreading.  Now trying my son's Elidel (for eczema), but still no change.Bumps are small, skin color or light pink, EXTREMELY itchy at times (but not all the time), they often then bleed (with or without itching them), and then the final (lovely) step is that they turn into purple-y scar-type things that are alarmingly dark when I'm cold.  those don't itch, but do seem to take a long time to go away.Help!  ??
title: Rash on shins
